column14: Old Swan Wharf, Battersea Church Road, London.  South bank of River Thames, within a small corner so tending to attract debris. Tide had just reached its highest point and started to go out as I took the sample. The concrete of the slipway showing in the photos was under water when I took the sample. I was reluctant to wade in too far because although wearing wellington boots the waves were sometimes choppy from passing boats and I wanted to keep the process simple without having to change trousers etc. The water was therefore shallow so the tip of the bottle was not very far beneath the surface of the water. Dense housing, offices and streets lined both shores of the river and close by was a line of houseboats moored along the river  bank. I chose this location because on looking into this, from a non-scientific source (ie Wikipedia), it seems this is a reasonable boundary below which the water begins to become saline as demonstrated by the characteristics of the fish generally found in that area. [Wikipedia says: The district of Teddington a few miles south-west of London's centre marks the boundary between the tidal and non-tidal parts of the Thames, although it is still considered a freshwater river about as far east as Battersea insofar as the average salinity is very low and the fish fauna consists predominantly of freshwater species such as roach, dace, carp, perch, and pike. The Thames Estuary becomes brackish between Battersea and Gravesend, and the diversity of freshwater fish species present is smaller, primarily roach and dace, euryhaline marine species such as flounder, European seabass, mullet, and smelt become much more common. Further east, the salinity increases and the freshwater fish species are completely replaced by euryhaline marine ones, until the river reaches Gravesend, at which point conditions become fully marine and the fish fauna resembles that of the adjacent North Sea and includes both euryhaline and stenohaline marine species.
